DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Will Have Whites, Businessmen, Opposition Parties
DOC.TEXT: Sam Nujoma, expected to be Namibia's first president, on Thursday named a white, a businessman and opposition party members to a Cabinet that will take power when the territory becomes independent next year. The announcement was seen as the latest move by Nujoma and his South-West Africa People's Organization to bring about reconciliation in the territory wracked by 23 years of war against South African rule. Leftist SWAPO captured last month's U.N.-supervised elections. The seven parties represented in the constituent assembly reached tentative agreement Wednesday on a constitution, and independence is likely to be declared in March, according to most observers. Nujoma named 14 of the 16 Cabinet posts, but did not fill the agriculture or wildlife ministries. Nujoma, a virtual certainty to become president, also left the prime minister's post open for the time being. The most prominent jobs all went to leading SWAPO members. But Nujoma also named Reinhold Rukoro of the Namibia National Front as deputy minister of justice and Reggie Diergaardt of the United Democratic Front as deputy minister for trade and industry. Also, a white accountant with no party affiliation, Gert Hanekom, was named auditor general. Zed Ngavirue, chairman of a private mining company, will head the National Planning Commission. Leftist SWAPO holds 41 of the 72 seats in the assembly. The Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, a multiracial coalition that favors a capitalist economy, has 21 seats. The remaining 10 seats are divided among five other parties. The draft constitution has a declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, speech and a free press. It also envisions a multiparty democracy, regular elections for two houses of Parliament, an executive president and an independent judiciary. SWAPO waged a bush war against South African rule of the territory from 1966 until April of this year. South Africa, which captured Namibia from Germany in 1915, will continue to administer the territory until independence. However, it has withdrawn all its troops. The more than 6,000 U.N. military and civilian personnel in Namibia are scheduled to remain until the end of March.
